So you want Szoboszlai, seeing the dangling leg, to actually fall into it naturally before going to ground and potentially injure himself in the process? Or does he avoid maximizing the contact and simply move to avoid the dangling leg? The leg should not have been dangling. It's clumsy and defenders know not to dangle legs like that in the box, almost guaranteed pen every time.

You do not understand the basics.  "Simulation" means something very specific: it is reacting to non-existent contact.  What Szobo did is called "going down soft", leaving his feet when he could have stayed up if he really wanted to.  Going down soft has never been illegal.  In fact, not only do referees generally have a problem with going down soft, top level referees have been known to actually tell players they need to go down to get the whistle. 

The real question you should ask yourself is whether you prefer players who decided to go down soft before contact, or players who decide after.  IMNSHO, the real cheaters are the ones who are swerving into defenders and are just dropping to the ground at the slightest touch.  Szobo here feels significant contact and then decides to go down.  The referee was not fooled by what Szobo did here, not even a little.

Go support a another team then, if that's what you want to watch. Liverpool has never been a defensively-oriented team, the entire footballing philosophy of the club is about playing attacking football, and that is how we became the team with most major honours in English football. The fans won't be having any scared football from their team!

Don't you watch football? Defenders can't dangle a leg in front of an attacker like that in the box, it's always gonna be a pen. He missed the ball and tripped the player. Actually follow through and fall into the offending leg on the way down = risk injury. Only option is to minimize contact.

Defenders can't just dangle a leg in such a clumsy way in the box against an attacking player, it's always gonna be a pen. Attacking players in that situation avoid following through and making too much contact with the offending limb to avoid potential injury. And If they don't go down the ref simply doesn't give it, so sadly players are forced into going down like a sack of spuds, as Szoboszlai did. Still a pen regardless, because you can't miss the ball and dangle a leg in front of a player in the box like that.

To preface this, I am a Chelsea fan - so any West Ham supporters feel free to tell me if I'm way off here.

It felt like half of the players here didn't know what they were doing tactically. Soucek was consistently caught out of position because he was being tasked with covering the entirety of midfield when Bowen wouldn't track back fast enough and Alvarez was stuck on the right side.
The entirety of the defense felt like they were in two minds about stretching to cover wide runs by Cucurella and Madueke or squeeze in to force them to cross, so they kind of did neither very well and allowed passes to slip in the half spaces between players
It really just felt like, tactically speaking, the team was set up to lose. There was no mind given to how Chelsea had set up against Spurs, so Cucurella was allowed to perform exactly the same free role he did in that game, completely overloading the midfield in possession.

I really don't think the players were to blame in a vacuum, the tactics just felt like they weren't thought through at all.

I would say three things...

1) I would like to see the front four eventually be more flexible and fluid in terms of covering each other defensively. 

2) I would also consider swapping Paqueta and Kudus's positions. I feel that there is a huge requirement for the 10 in that system to support Antonio's press, and we may upset the opposition's build-up more with Kudus taking that role rather than Paqueta. You also gain the link-up between Emerson and Paqueta down the left-hand side that we have seen so frequently this season. This is a consideration rather than an out-and-out suggestion.

3) I agreed with the decision to make a defensive sub at the 65-minute mark, but my sub at the time would have been Phillips for Antonio, go 4-5-1, push Paqueta to the left, and rather than leave Bowen up top, I would have opted for Kudus to be the makeshift CF. 

All in all, it's a relatively new system and there may be tweaks that incrementally improve us. I would have liked this 11 to start the season as soon as Kudus arrived.

It's been excellent so far. We look like we are overwhelming teams at times which is great to see. I still think there is a place for that 'low-block' system that Moyes has employed so frequently this season, but I would like it to be used in 20% of the games, rather than 80%. 

Just my takes from the game.

We are looking like a really, really good side again. If we can continue in the same vein and overwhelm certain teams and revert back to the system we used more frequently at the beginning of the season against certain sides, I think it gives us two ways of getting results.

I mean I know it sounds ridiculous to say this when we literally lost 6-0 BUT I don't actually think we played THAT badly, well at least not 6-0 badly anyway! 
Because if you actually look at the 6 goals, analyse them and break them down then you'll see that the first 3 were all set pieces! 
They had a corner, a penalty and a free-kick all set pieces! 
So if we had only just avoided giving those set pieces away, then obviously it would have only been 3-0 which I know still isn't great but losing 3-0 to Arsenal these days is no disgrace whatsoever! 
I think 6-0 is flattering, we didn't deserve that because I actually think we contained them and defended pretty well for the first half an hour before they scored, we just inexplicably collapsed once they did and sadly the floodgates then opened but 6 is definitely not the complete story of the game imo

Attractive??? Just negative football dude

@muhammadfurqan7952  Negative? Hahahaha - it was the perfect counter-attacking team... soak up the pressure, wait for a mistake and pounce. There is nothing negative about that. It takes huge resilience, concentration and skill, especially in the transition... 

You can only use what you have. There are teams like Brighton that are set up to hold possession and move the ball, but usually those teams struggle against the really good teams that are as good defensively as they are in attack. Many of the top teams combine both counter-attacking and possession football, because they have the type of top players who can do both. 

Too often, our players lose the ball in positions where top teams hold onto to it and can build a possession based attack. Usually, we are better at this as the season progresses, and I think as Paqueta, Alvarez, WP and Kudus become familiar with each other, we will have better play through the middle. 

The problem I see for us over and over is the inability to deal with the high press... so we end up having to do defend rather than break out or even just thread the ball. The high press creates an overlap, so it's three against two, and in that situation, we have come unstuck so many times. It's like we don't see the press working, or we give the ball to a player who doesn't have space, hasn't created space, or cannot handle the close pressure. At least with Rice, we had some composure in those areas. It's no surprise to me that since Rice left, our possession ratio has gone down. We need Paqueta to be able to use his skills and positioning to be the pivot so that we can handle that high press better. 

It isn't just about the manager saying 'I want us to play defensively'. No manager ever says that. But a manager will say 'if we cannot win the game, let's not lose it', and that is something that West Ham have done so much in my 40+ years of following them. Moyes is the first manager I've seen who actually knows how to properly organise a defence, with the possible exception of Rednapp.
